docs.lead_paragraph: They will gather Friday afternoon at Blondie's Restaurant on West 79th Street to reminisce about Cecile and Peter's disastrous wedding, the time Lila gave birth in a stalled elevator at the Lumina Ball, about Frankie's murder and when Vicky, hovering between life and death, met Ryan in heaven. Then at 2 P.M., they will tune to ''Another World'' for the last time and say goodbye to Carl and Rachel, Joe and Paulina and Vicky and Jake, and after 35 years and 8,891 episodes, one of television's most venerable soap operas will be no more.

headline.main: As the World Turns, Soap Operas Wane And Viewers Grieve

docs.abstract: Another World, NBC's longest-running daytime soap opera, will end on June 24 after 35 years, the victim of decline in soap opera audiences caused by entry of women into workplace, changing routines for those at home and competition from daytime talk shows; estimates are that soaps have lost quarter of audience over last 10 years; two of five weeklies that follow soaps have closed down, no successful new soap has been introduced over last decade, and shows are increasingly resorting to guest appearances or outlandish gimmick plots to keep audiences; so-called prime-time soaps that flourished in 1980's are almost all gone, and rumors are rampant about which remaining ones are most imperiled; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ROBERT FRANCOEUR has an improbable resume: He is an ordained Roman Catholic priest who is married with two children and has made a career of the study of sex. He is a professor of evolutionary biology at Fairleigh Dickinson University who says he has never felt uncomfortable with the biblical creation story. (''One is based on history,'' he says, '' the other meaning and science.'') He is as comfortable to be around as a favorite uncle, yet his unassuming home in Rockaway is filled with an array of erotica from around the world to make the most sexually savvy blush.
docs.abstract: Profile of Robert Francoeur of New Jersey, ordained Roman Catholic priest who is married with two children and teaches sexuality at Fairleigh Dickinson University; he has written books and articles on sexuality and spirituality and collects erotica from around world; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITHOUT question, he's the best known weatherman in Connecticut through his long association with the oldest television station in the state -- WTNH-TV Channel 8 of New Haven -- and through a daily weather column that runs in a half-dozen papers including the state's biggest, The Hartford Courant. His name is Melvin Goldstein, but he is generally known as Dr. Mel, a low-key person who looks like everyone's favorite uncle and who has never succumbed to the notion that TV weathermen must have gimmicks to survive.

headline.main: An Expert in an Inexact Science

docs.abstract: Profile of Melvin Goldstein, longtime weatherman at WTNH-TV Channel 8 in New Haven, Conn; he comments on his career, current bout with bone cancer and thalidomide treatments; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Though the nation's infant mortality rate has steadily declined over the last decade, the percentage of women who die in childbirth has remained essentially unchanged, and black women are four times as likely to die as whites, according to a Government study released today. Dying while giving birth is still rare in this country. For every 100,000 women who have babies, the study found, 7.7 die, a figure that translates into the death of 1 mother for every 12,987 giving birth.

headline.main: Racial Divide Found in Maternal Mortality

docs.abstract: Government study shows that though nation's infant mortality rate has steadily declined over last decade, percentage of women who die in childbirth has remained essentially unchanged, and black women are four times as likely to die as whites; study findings reviewed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ANOTHER ho-hum seven days in the legal salt mines for Thomas A. Moore, whose date book probably reads something like this: Friday, win $76.4 million verdict against New York City. Tuesday, win legal motion that helps insulate April verdict of $54 million. Yesterday, opening arguments, new trial. Given that Mr. Moore has captured 66 verdicts of more than $1 million each and is admired -- also envied, feared and thoroughly despised -- as one of the country's pre-eminent medical malpractice lawyers, it is a tad galling to hear him complain.
docs.abstract: Public Lives profile of Thomas A Moore, prominent medical malpractice lawyer who recently won $76.4 million verdict against New York City for Gaelle Prindilus, brain-injured child who was born with umbilical cord around her neck; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the tall man talks, people tend to listen. They have to, because he speaks so softly. So the other day, in a room overlooking San Francisco Bay, maybe three dozen environmentalists listened closely as Bill Bradley led them through a discussion that began with the wind in the sycamore trees in his home town on the Mississippi River in Crystal City, Mo., then threaded its way through the thickets of California's water wars and finally, almost by chance, to the point. ''For me, there's only one reason to run for President of the United States,'' Mr. Bradley told a listener who asked him why he was doing it. ''That's because you think your leadership could improve the quality of life for millions of Americans. I look at my situation and think ability matches the moment.'' That understated answer distills the way Mr. Bradley has campaigned up and down California this week: personally, peacefully, almost obliquely. From a storefront black church in South-Central Los Angeles to a mentoring program for minority teen-agers and new immigrants in Sacramento, from an earnest discussion with underpaid home-care workers to a playful pass through the Farmer's Market in Hollywood, where he made like Meadowlark Lemon with a couple of a cantaloupes, his style has been the same: he talks quietly about the issues that drive him, like race relations or the environment, and lets everything else -- including his candidacy -- speak for itself. On this road trip, there is no set stump speech, no repeated slogan, few snappy sound-bites. There is just a tall man talking. ''I wanted in this trip, notwithstanding what the pundits have said, to show that you can campaign in California person-to-person and succeed,'' Mr. Bradley said of his nine-day swing through the Golden State. The trip is a bit of creative counter-programming that has kept his underdog presence on the radar screen as Vice President Al Gore, his rival for the Democratic nomination, officially kicks off his candidacy today in Tennessee. ''I want to show respect for the voters of California,'' he said, ''just like I show respect for the voters of Iowa or New Hampshire.'' Almost no one thinks that retail campaigning is the way to win in California, where politics sometimes seems to exist only in paid television advertising and the disembodied debates of direct mail. But as he finally embraces the quest for the Presidency that he has considered and rejected so many times before, Bill Bradley is not -- ostentatiously not -- a candidate who buys what everyone else thinks. And for better or worse, as he lopes along, trailing Mr. Gore in California by worse than 2 to 1 in the latest Los Angeles Times Poll, Mr. Bradley, more than ever, seems to have a sense of where he is. There is still the lanky 6-foot-5-inch grace that marked his years as a basketball star for Princeton and the New York Knicks, and the cool, cerebral blend of diffidence and directness that suffused his 18 years in the Senate from New Jersey. But two and a half years after Mr. Bradley left Washington for writing and teaching, there is something else as well: a kind of Zenlike calm and self-acceptance that makes him seem looser, easier, lighter than he did on Capitol Hill, when he tended to come forth periodically with carefully wrought pronouncements on topics like trade, taxes or race but otherwise often stayed above the fray. ''I developed a real peace of mind about what I'm doing now,'' Mr. Bradley said in an interview between campaign stops on Tuesday. ''I have a clear sense of why I want to do it, what I want to do and how I want to do it. I'm just being myself.'' Mr. Bradley is not running the anarchic, outsider campaign of a Jerry Brown or Ross Perot. There are plenty of traditional campaign-style events, including a Beverly Hills fund-raiser to be headed by the entertainment mogul Barry Diller on Thursday and the structured sessions of empathetic discussion with diverse constituent groups that President Clinton has made de rigueur in contemporary politics. He acknowledges that television advertising will be important and today made a traditional policy speech on child poverty, reading from a prepared text, at Para Los Ninos, a child-care center on Skid Row downtown. ''After seven years of the first two-term Democratic administration since Franklin Roosevelt, the percentage of American children living in poverty has barely changed,'' Mr. Bradley said, calling for greater parental involvement and improved day-care standards, but omitting the most specific proposals in the news release circulated by his staff: raising the minimum wage and expanding the Federal earned-income tax credit for working families. All the same, he is striving to do things differently. He has yet to take a poll, for example, and is ''not trying to be some kind of political mannequin,'' as he told a Los Angeles television reporter. Or, as he told environmentalists in San Francisco, he hopes to construct, ''a narrative and some coherence to all these things that are occurring in people's lives.'' ''I think the way politics are done today, too often you try to be somebody else,'' Mr. Bradley said in an interview. ''And I think that quite frankly the press is bored with this as much as the politician is bored with it. And I think the idea of my relating to the press, meaning standing before some backdrop and saying three or four poll tested phrases in an attempt to manipulate you only makes you angrier and therefore your job is to destroy, or as you would say, unmask, the candidate, and basically on both sides of the equation it's boring. So my view is my job is to make something happen with people out there.'' How well that approach will work, and how well Mr. Bradley can execute it, remains to be seen. He says his top priorities will be to ''be a good steward of a good economy,'' protect the environment, insure that ''every child in America has a chance to realize his or her potential,'' and to overhaul campaign finance laws, but those are not vastly different from Mr. Gore's. And although Mr. Bradley has criticized Mr. Gore as relying on small-bore ideas, some of his own proposals are not exactly giant, like the notion of creating ''15-month houses'' where unwed teen-age mothers could live under supervision in the final months of pregnancy and the first months of their child's life to learn parenting skills. For his part, as he joked with political reporters in Sacramento on Monday, Mr. Bradley took heart from the underdog performance of his old team. ''I think,'' he said dryly, ''the Knicks are proving that speed and quickness are more important than bulk.''

headline.main: Bradley Takes On California, One on One

docs.abstract: Former Sen Bill Bradley takes his campaign for Democratic nomination for President to California; is eschewing set stump speeches and snappy slogans and is talking quietly about issues that drive him; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: George W. Bush, the man in the monogrammed cowboy boots, reconnected tonight with the Yankee roots he so often plays down, at the end of a day on which his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination gave him his harshest taste yet of the political perils that lie along the campaign trail. On the final stop of his first campaign swing, Mr. Bush was showered with $1.3 million at a dinner crowning him the adopted favorite son of Greenwich, which considers itself ground zero for Bushes although the candidate himself has never lived here.

headline.main: Bush Draws Donations, And Conservatives' Fire

docs.abstract: Texas Gov George W Bush, Republican Presidential frontrunner, receives $1.3 million in final stop of first campaign swing in Greenwich, Conn, where he is crowned at fund-raising dinner as city's favorite son; conservative rivals for nomination give him harshest taste yet of political perils that lie along campaign trail, criticizing him for remarks about prospective judicial appointees in Bush administration who he said would be conservative but would not be required to share his views on specific issues, such as abortion; photo (M)
docs.snippet: George W. Bush, the man in the monogrammed cowboy boots, reconnected tonight with the Yankee roots  he so often plays down, at the end of a day on which his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination gave him his harshest taste yet of the...

docs.lead_paragraph: New mothers are staying in the hospital a little longer -- about half a day more on average, according to the first study conducted since a public outcry over ''drive-by deliveries.'' The trend began even before a Federal law requiring insurance coverage of 48-hour stays went into effect. In the early 1990's, many insurance companies began paying only for 24-hour hospital stays for vaginal deliveries.

headline.main: Moms Gaining Time in Maternity Wards

docs.abstract: Study shows that new mothers are staying in hospital a little longer--about half day more on average--in first study conducted since public outcry over 'driveby deliveries'; trend began even before Federal law requiring insurance coverage of 48-hour stays went into effect (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A jury has ordered the Health and Hospitals Corporation to pay $76.4 million to a 12-year-old girl who suffered brain damage and other permanent injuries during her birth in what her lawyer called a botched delivery at Harlem Hospital Center. It was one of the largest malpractice verdicts ever recorded against the corporation, which runs the city's hospitals. The award, returned last Friday by a State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan, was made to Gaelle Prindilus, who was born on Jan. 16, 1987. The lawyer, Thomas A. Moore, said yesterday that she was born with her umbilical cord wrapped around her neck and with no medical personnel in the hospital room to attend her mother, Yverose Prindilus, who underwent 17 hours of labor.

headline.main: Hospitals Unit Found Liable In Birth Injury

docs.abstract: State Supreme Court jury orders Health and Hospitals Corp to pay $76.4 million to Gaelle Prindilus, 12-year-old girl who suffered brain damage and other permanent injuries during her birth in what her lawyer, Thomas A Moore, calls botched delivery at Harlem Hospital Center; it is one of largest malpractice verdicts ever recorded against corporation; Moore says Prindilus was born on Jan 16, 1987 with her umbilical cord wrapped around her neck and with no medical personnel in hospital room to attend her mother Yverose, who underwent 17 hours of labor; Gaelle Prindilus suffers from cerebral palsy, requires wheelchair and is unable to read or write (M)
